page.title: 17GEOLOGY OF LIMPSFIELD
page.content: Limpsfield is a typical medieval strip parish, identical to its neighbours of Oxted, Tandridge and Godstone in cutting across four geological outcrops. Limpsfield village developed from Domesday times on the dip slope of the{Lower {Greensand Ridge}escarpment where the water table throws out springs. The High Street has eleven wells. The Greensand also provided ironstone and ragstone for building. At the scarp foot the{Gault Clay formed a broad vale picked out by the {River Eden}liable to flooding but providing wet meadowland. Sheltering the vale, the{North Downs chalk escarpment gave arable land along the lower slopes and beechwoods for pigs on the sharp scarp edge. South of the{Greensand}the Wealden forests gave oak for timber housing.
